choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Apoferritin is the storage form.
Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

 

Iron metabolism involves complex processes where iron must be in the correct oxidation state to be absorbed and utilized effectively by the body. Iron in the diet is primarily found in the ferric (Fe3+) form, but for it to be absorbed across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the intestine, it needs to be converted into the ferrous (Fe2+) form. This conversion is crucial because only ferrous iron can be effectively transported into the cells. The statement in option A is incorrect because it suggests the opposite process—conversion from ferrous to ferric—before absorption, which is not accurate. The conversion actually goes from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) before iron is absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: This statement is correct. Apoferritin binds with iron to form ferritin, which is the storage form of iron within cells.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood: This is also correct. After iron is absorbed into the bloodstream, it binds to the protein transferrin, which transports it to various tissues, including the bone marrow for hemoglobin production.

 

Option D. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: This statement is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) reduces ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which enhances its absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron must be converted from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form for effective absorption through the apical membrane of enterocytes

questions.text: Which form of cutaneous tuberculosis is typically contracted from direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis

 

  • Tuberculosis verrusosa cutis (TBVC) is the form of cutaneous tuberculosis that results from direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin of individuals with good immunity. 
  • It is also called "Anatomist's wart" or "Pathologist's wart" because of its occupational association. 
  • TVC presents as an indurated verrucous plaque that develops at the site of inoculation, typically on trauma-prone sites like the extremities. 

 

 

  • Due to the patient's good immunity, this is a paucibacillary form of cutaneous TB where the infection remains localized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scrofuloderma:

 

  • Scrofuloderma is an endogenous form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs through contiguous spread from an underlying tuberculous focus (lymph node, bone, joint) to the overlying skin. 

 

 

  • It is not acquired through direct skin inoculation. 
  • Scrofuloderma is characterized by painless subcutaneous swellings that break down to form discharging sinuses with undermined edges.

 

Option B. Lupus Vulgaris:

 

  • Lupus Vulgaris can occur through both endogenous (hematogenous spread) and, less commonly, exogenous routes, but it typically affects individuals with moderate immunity rather than good immunity. 
  • It presents as a plaque with an active, advancing margin and central scarring. 

 

 

 

  • While it can occasionally be acquired through direct inoculation, it's not the typical presentation in individuals with good immunity, so TBVC is the better option to choose.

 

Option D. Any of the above:

 

  • Only Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is specifically associated with direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is distinguished as the form of cutaneous TB acquired through exogenous inoculation in individuals with good immunity, presenting as a localized verrucous plaque at trauma-prone sites, particularly on the extremities.

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Satellite lesion

 

Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

 

The signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reverse hypopyon:  "Reverse hypopyon" can form when emulsified silicone oil used during vitreoretinal surgery enters the anterior chamber of the eye. The silicone oil floats in the aqueous to look like a layered hypopyon in the upper portion of the anterior chamber. Silicone Oil in anterior chamber is called hyperoleon.

 

 

Inverted or reverse hypopyon as a result of emulsification into the anterior chamber. Migration of silicon oil into the anterior chamber displaces aqueous inferiorly and results in a density gradient demarcation line.

 

Option B. Dendritic ulcer on fluorescein dye: Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

 

Pseudodendritic ulcer is caused by acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Ring abscess: Can be seen in recurrent stromal herpes keratitis or acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Satellite lesions around the main ulcer are characteristic of fungal corneal ulcers, along with irregular margins, immune rings, and potentially immobile hypopyon.

questions.text: What is the most important assessment based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management in a health care facility? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Process

 

Evaluation of "process" can assess a health care facility based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management.

 

The process of evaluation involves several steps, such as

 

  • Determining what needs to be evaluated
  • Establishing standards and criteria
  • Planning the methodology
  • Gathering information
  • Analyzing the results
  • Taking action
  • Re-evaluating

 

There are three types of evaluation: structure evaluation, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation.

 

  1. Evaluation of "structure": This is evaluation of whether facilities, equipment, manpower and organization meet a standard accepted by experts as good.
  2. Evaluation of "process": The process of medical care includes the problems of recognition, diagnostic procedures, treatment and clinical management, care and prevention. The way in which the various activities of the programme is carried out is evaluated by comparing with a predetermined standard. An objective and systematic way of evaluating the physician (or nurse) performance is known as "Medical (or nursing) Audit"
  3. Evaluation of "outcome": This is concerned with the end results, that is, whether persons using health services experience measurable benefits such as improved survival or reduced disability. The traditional outcome components are the "5 Ds" of ill-health, viz. disease, discomfort, dissatisfaction, disability and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outcome: Focuses on the end results of healthcare, such as improved health status and reduced disease and disability.

 

  • Not Correct: It measures the results of care, not the processes used to deliver it.

 

Option C. Structure: Examines the physical and organizational infrastructure, like facilities, equipment, and staffing.

 

  • Not Correct: It evaluates resources and infrastructure, not the actual delivery of care.

 

Option D. Input: Assesses resources required for healthcare, such as funding, manpower, and materials.

 

  • Not Correct: It looks at the resources used, not how care is delivered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "process" evaluation is the most relevant assessment for determining the quality of treatment and clinical management provided to patients in a healthcare facility. It focuses on the procedures and methods used in patient care, ensuring adherence to established standards and guidelines.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

  • Obstructed labor is a direct indication for an emergency cesarean section
  • Obstructed labor happens when despite good uterine contractions, labor does not progress due to problems in the maternal pelvis/ fetus or a mechanical obstruction
  • Features of Obstructed Labor:
  • Maternal exhaustion and dehydration
  • Abdominal examination
    • Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker
    • Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out
    • Fetal parts not easily felt
    • Round ligaments taut and tender
    • Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring)
    • Fetal heart rate absent
  • Vaginal exam
    • Vagina feels hot and dry
    • Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain
    • Caput +++
    • Moulding +++
    • Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • The mainstay of management will be to start IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Emergency LSCS is the rule in Obstructed labor even in a dead fetus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniotomy: This is a destructive fetal operation which is not preferred anymore even in a non-viable fetus/ dead fetus. It can be done if ffacilities for immediate cesarean are not available.  The main indications for fetal craniotomy are:

 

  • Cephalic presentation with obstructed labour
  • Hydrocephalus in a living fetus
  • Interlocking head of twins
  • Aftercoming head of breech

 

Option B. Decapitation: It is severing of the fetal head from the trunk. It is a destructive operation and again is not preferred unless facilities for emergency LSCS are not available or in exceptional circumstances. Indications are

 

  • Neglected shoulder with a dead fetus
  • Locked twins

 

Option D. Forceps extraction: Instrumental delivery is contra-indicated in obstructed labor. CPD should be ruled out prior to applying an instrument (Forceps or vacuum)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is the recommended management, even if the fetus is deceased.

 

Ref: Page no 421, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A man running a 40-kilometre marathon on a hot summer afternoon suddenly collapsed before completing his race. On examination, his body temperature was 104 degrees, but there were no physical signs of dehydration. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

The case scenario is suggestive of a heatstroke in this patient. Heatstroke / heat exhaustion occurs when the body can no longer control its temperature. The body's temperature rises rapidly, the sweating mechanism fails, and the body is unable to cool down. When heat stroke occurs, the body temperature can rise to 106°F or higher within 10 to 15 minutes.

 

In this case it is due to prolonged exposure to the sun during running.

 

Management - Rapidly cooling the body with cold blankets till temperature falls below 102 degrees Celsius.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot skin: Likely to be present due to the high body temperature in heatstroke.

 

Option B. Hypotension: Can be seen due to vasodilation and possible dehydration.

 

Option D. Disorientation: Likely due to neurological dysfunction caused by the extreme heat affecting the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Whole Bowel Irrigation

 

The child has ingested a significant amount of ferrous sulfate, leading to iron intoxication, which has resulted in metabolic acidosis. Managing iron overdose requires specific interventions.

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Iron Intoxication: Iron overdose is a common pediatric poisoning that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Ingesting a large number of ferrous sulfate tablets can result in gastrointestinal irritation, systemic toxicity, and metabolic acidosis.
  2. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Revealed Acidosis: Metabolic acidosis is a severe consequence of iron poisoning, indicating systemic toxicity.

 

Management of Iron Intoxication:

 

  • Whole Bowel Irrigation (WBI): This is a key intervention for decontaminating the gastrointestinal tract in cases of iron overdose. WBI is performed using a polyethylene glycol-electrolyte solution to flush out the gastrointestinal contents. It is particularly useful when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Antidote: The specific antidote for iron poisoning is deferoxamine, which binds free iron and promotes its excretion. While deferoxamine is essential in managing iron toxicity, it is not listed as an option in this question.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Activated Charcoal: As mentioned, it is not effective for iron, alcohols, acids, alkalis, or petroleum product intoxications. Activated charcoal does not adsorb iron, making it unsuitable for treating iron overdose.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Used for heavy metal poisoning like arsenic, gold, and mercury, but not effective for iron.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Used primarily for heavy metal poisoning like copper and lead, and ineffective for iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole Bowel Irrigation with polyethylene glycol is the preferred method for managing iron tablet ingestion, especially when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via increase in cAMP. There are several steps involved in this mechanism as given below. Which of the following is correct sequence of events in cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET May 2024)

 

Steps involved


1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
2. Activation of PKA
3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway is:

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  3. Activation of PKA
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: B. 1, 3, 2 and 4

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

 

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

 

This is a rare type of breast cancer that occurs more frequently in older women and grows slowly. The prognosis of colloid carcinoma is better than that of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

 

The tumor is typically a soft, gelatinous mass with well-defined borders.

 

Histologically, colloid carcinoma has a lot of extracellular epithelial mucin and mucin-filled acini. Floating in large lakes of mucin are cuboidal to tall columnar tumor cells, some of which show mucus vacuolation. Nuclei in intracellular type are pushed to the periphery, forming a signet ring appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary carcinoma of the breast is characterized by the presence of papillary structures lined by neoplastic cells.

 

  • It does not typically present with large pools of mucin.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is characterized by large, high-grade cells with a syncytial growth pattern, prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders.

 

  • It lacks the extensive mucin pools seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single-file lines or targetoid patterns.

 

  • It typically lacks the mucin pools characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

questions.text: Which of the following refractory condition is depicted in the figure.  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Astigmatism

 

Astigmatism occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular shape, preventing light from focusing properly on the retina. This leads to blurred or distorted vision at all distances. Common symptoms include eyestrain, headaches, and difficulty seeing at night.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: This is a common condition associated with aging, where the eye's lens loses its ability to change shape to focus on close objects. Symptoms include difficulty reading small print or having to hold reading material farther away. Presbyopia typically starts to become noticeable in the early to mid-40s.

 

Option B. Myopia (Nearsightedness): This condition occurs when the eye is longer than normal or has a cornea that is too curved. As a result, light rays focus in front of the retina instead of on it. This leads to distant objects appearing blurry while close objects are seen clearly. Myopia is often identified in childhood or adolescence and can worsen during periods of rapid growth.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia (Farsightedness): In this condition, the eye is shorter than normal, or the cornea is not curved enough, causing light to focus behind the retina. This makes close objects appear blurry, while distant objects are usually seen clearly. Children often have some degree of hypermetropia, which can decrease as the eye grows and lengthens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and understanding these refractive conditions is essential for early detection and management. Regular eye examinations are crucial, as they allow for the timely prescription of corrective lenses or other treatments. Each condition affects vision in a unique way, and understanding these differences is key in providing effective patient care and guidance.

choices.text: Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons

questions.text: Mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons

 

This is the correct mechanism of action. Botulinum toxin works by blocking the release of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter, from lower motor neurons. This inhibition prevents the transmission of nerve signals to muscle cells, leading to muscle paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits NM receptor: Botulinum toxin does not directly inhibit the neuromuscular (NM) receptor. Instead, it affects the neuromuscular junction but not by inhibiting the receptor itself.

 

Option B. Inhibits reuptake of acetylcholine: Botulinum toxin does not inhibit the reuptake of acetylcholine. Its primary mode of action is different.

 

Option D. Inhibits synthesis of acetylcholine: Botulinum toxin does not inhibit the synthesis of acetylcholine. It mainly interferes with the release and function of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin, produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum, exerts its mechanism of action by preventing the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. The toxin cleaves specific proteins involved in vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release, leading to the inhibition of acetylcholine release from lower motor neurons. This blockade of acetylcholine release results in muscle paralysis, making botulinum toxin useful for medical and cosmetic purposes to treat conditions characterized by excessive muscle activity.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 587

questions.text: Under MTP Act of India, for cases of MTP after 24 weeks POG, there has to be a Medical board to advise. It comprises of all except: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Legal advisor


Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, a Medical Board must be constituted for termination of pregnancy beyond 24 weeks, specifically in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. This board plays a crucial role in evaluating the circumstances and approving the procedure when necessary. The Medical Board is required to have specific members to provide expert medical advice, including:

 

  1. An Obstetrician-Gynaecologist who provides expertise on maternal and fetal health.
  2. A Radiologist who is crucial for diagnosing fetal anomalies through imaging.
  3. A Paediatrician who offers insights into the potential viability and health of the fetus.
  4. Members nominated by state government in official Gazette

 

These experts collectively evaluate the condition to ensure a medically sound decision. However, the board does not include a legal advisor, as their role is primarily medical, focusing on the health aspects rather than legal counsel.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The Medical Board for MTP cases beyond 24 weeks includes an Obstetrician-Gynaecologist, Radiologist, and Paediatrician but does not include a legal advisor.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age less than -2SD: This defines moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), not severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

 

Option B. Weight for height less than +2SD: This would indicate overnutrition or obesity, not malnutrition.

 

Option C. Weight for age less than +3SD: This is not relevant to malnutrition and could indicate overnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text: In a community, there were 550 births in a year out of which 50 were stillbirths. There were 09 deaths among newborns during 0-7 days of life. An additional 41 deaths occurred during 8-28 days of life. Calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality rate for the given community. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 18

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) measures the number of deaths of newborns within the first 7 days of life per 1,000 live births. It focuses specifically on early neonatal deaths, which occur during the first week of life.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 550
  • Stillbirths: 50
  • Live births (LB): 550 - 50 = 500
  • Early Neonatal Deaths (ENND): 9 deaths during 0-7 days.

 

ENMR formula:

 

 

Therefore, the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is 18 deaths per 1,000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is calculated as the number of early neonatal deaths (0-7 days) per 1,000 live births.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Additional 300kcal in 2nd trimester

 

Explanation:

 

  • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester.
  • As per Williams Obstetrics:
    • In the first trimester, no extra calories are required.
    • In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day.
    • In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended.
  • Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Additional 300kcal in 1st trimester: No extra calories are recommended in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Additional 300kcal in 3rd trimester: The recommendation for the third trimester is an increase of approximately 452 kcal per day.

 

Option D. Additional 300kcal throughout the pregnancy: Caloric requirements vary by trimester, with no extra calories needed in the first trimester, and specific increases for the second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the caloric requirements and recommendations for each trimester of pregnancy to ensure adequate maternal and fetal nutrition.

 

Ref: Page 483, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the Causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The clinical presentation of severe headache, high fever, papilloedema, and nuchal rigidity, combined with the Gram stain results, is highly indicative of meningococcal meningitis, caused by Neisseria meningitidis. The image from the Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci supports this diagnosis. Neisseria meningitidis is known for appearing as gram-negative diplococci, often resembling kidney beans, and typically found within white blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

 

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus and typically presents with tumbling motility in liquid media, not as diplococci.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis - Intracellular gram-negative diplococci in gram staining.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.

 

  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.
  • This maneuver involves tilting the patient's head backward by gently lifting the chin upward.
  • It is used to open the airway and clear any potential obstruction in the upper part of the throat.
  • This is a basic technique used in CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) to help with ventilation.

 

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: The jaw thrust maneuver is used to open the airway in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. Instead of tilting the head backward, the anesthesiologist uses their fingers to push the patient's jaw forward. This technique avoids movement of the neck and is often used when spinal injury is a concern.

 

 

Option C. Head extension: Head extension involves simply tilting the patient's head backward to open the airway. It is similar to the head tilt, chin lift maneuver, but it focuses more on extending the neck to clear the airway.

 

 

Option D. In line manual stabilization: This technique is used to stabilize the cervical spine, especially in cases of suspected neck injuries. It involves maintaining the head and neck in a neutral, aligned position to prevent further injury during maneuvers like intubation. This is typically done by an assistant while another healthcare provider performs airway management.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.
  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C3b

 

C3b functions as an opsonin.

 

Opsonization: - The process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The substances involved in this process are called opsonins.

 

Include:

 

  • Mannose-binding lectin
  • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG
  • CRP
  • Fibrinogen
  • C3b, C4b, C5b

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. C3a and C. C5a: These are anaphylatoxins involved in inflammation and promoting chemotaxis.

 

Option D. C6: Part of the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C3b is an opsonin important in the immune system for marking pathogens for phagocytosis, enhancing the body's ability to clear infections.

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 months

 

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months.

 

 

Fig: Bidextrous grasp approach to a dangling ring 4 months

 

Fine motor development:

 

  • Hands come together in midline by 5 months
  • Bidextrous Reach comes by 4 months
  • Tries to reach for object from both hand will be bidextrous approach & from one hand will be unidextrous approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bidextrous reach, where a baby uses both hands to reach out for objects, is typically achieved by 4 months of age.

choices.text: Supposititious child

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins belonging to two different fathers. This case would be best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfecundation

 

  • Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus 
    • So twin pregnancy in both
    • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both Superfecundation and superfetation
  • Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
    • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time, whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

 

In the question, it is mentioned that “woman gave birth to twins”, which implies that both babies were born at same time. Hence superfecundation is a better choice than superfetation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: Fertilization of a second ovum during a different menstrual cycle while a pregnancy is already ongoing. The first fetus is more developed than the second, and they may not be born at the same time.

 

Option C. Supposititious children are fraudulent offspring. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine.

 

Option D. Atavism: A modification of a biological structure whereby an ancestral genetic trait reappears after having been lost through evolutionary change in previous generations. E.g. tail in humans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two ova from separate acts of coitus within the same menstrual cycle, resulting in the birth of twins that can have different fathers and are born at the same time.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

 

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae is primarily through the prostatic venous plexus or Bateson plexus. Tumor cells spread to the spine and proximal long bones via Bateson's venous plexus, which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.
  • The prostatic venous plexus (or Bateson plexus) is a network of veins surrounding the prostate.
  • The prostatic venous plexus has connections to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because of this unique venous anatomy, tumor cells from the prostate can enter the venous system and bypass the usual portal and caval routes, spreading directly to the spine, specifically the lumbar vertebrae.
  • This is the most common route for metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans coelomic spread: Trans coelomic spread refers to the dissemination of malignant cells across body cavities, such as the pleural, peritoneal, or pericardial spaces. This method of spread is most commonly seen with primary cancers of the ovary, stomach, and colon. In the context of prostate cancer, trans coelomic spread is not a typical route to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Option C. Inferior vesical vein: The inferior vesical vein drains the urinary bladder. While there are venous communications between the prostatic plexus and the vesical veins, the direct spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae through the inferior vesical vein alone is less common than through the prostatic venous plexus.

 

Option D. Internal iliac vein: The internal iliac vein drains blood from the pelvis and perineum. While prostate cancer can spread through the internal iliac vein as part of its venous drainage, this route is not the primary pathway to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are included in qSOFA score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SBP, RR, GCS score

 

  • The Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score is used to identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit.
  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria:
    1. Respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min: A high respiratory rate indicates respiratory distress and a higher risk of organ failure.
    2. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg: Low blood pressure indicates hemodynamic instability and a higher risk of mortality.
    3. Change in mental status (GCS score): Altered mental status, measured by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), indicates possible central nervous system dysfunction.
  • Each criterion is assigned one point, and a qSOFA score of ≥2 suggests a higher risk of adverse outcomes and increased mortality.

 

qSOFA (Quick SOFA) Criteria

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP, RR, and CBC: This option includes blood pressure and respiratory rate, but the complete blood count (CBC) is not part of the qSOFA score.

 

Option B. Creatinine, PR, BP:  Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are not part of the qSOFA score. Blood pressure is included, but the qSOFA score focuses on systolic blood pressure specifically.

 

Option C. RR, Body temperature, PR: Respiratory rate is part of the qSOFA score, but body temperature and pulse rate are not included.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score).
  • A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female pseudohermaphroditism

 

The most frequent enzyme deficiency leading to Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which typically manifests as female pseudohermaphroditism. Female pseudohermaphroditism refers to the presentation of a genotypically normal female (46, XX) who has external genitalia that resembles those of a male. The female is virilized, which means there is a masculinization of the body, and this virilization is usually evident at birth in females and within the first 2 to 3 years of life in males.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male pseudohermaphroditism: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17a-hydroxylase deficiency due to incomplete virilization.

 

Option C. True hermaphroditism: True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH.

 

Option D. 46 XY intersex: 46 XY intersex (now called 46 XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 33-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, 17-Hydroxylase/17,20-Lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, typically presents as female pseudohermaphroditism, characterized by virilized genitalia in genotypic females (46, XX) at birth.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is most likely affected here ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Interossei and lumbricals

 

  • Damage to the ulnar nerve can lead to weakness or atrophy of the lumbrical and interossei muscles in the hand.
  • These muscles play a crucial role in flexing the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extending the interphalangeal (IP) joints through their attachment to the dorsal digital expansions.
  • As a result of the nerve injury, the MCP joints may become extended, while the IP joints may become flexed.

 

Note: The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for

 

  • First and second lumbrical
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor digitorum: This muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts into the dorsal digital expansions of the medial four fingers.

 

  • It acts primarily to extend the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and interphalangeal (IP) joints of the fingers.
  • If the extensor digitorum were affected, you would expect difficulty in extending the MCP and IP joints.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis: 

  • It refers to two muscles, the abductor pollicis longus (located in the forearm) and abductor pollicis brevis (intrinsic hand muscle) whose primary function is to abduct the thumb. Dysfunction would primarily impact thumb movements and would not lead to the clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: 

  • It is one of the thenar muscles of the hand and plays a key role in thumb movement, especially in its abduction. Like the abductor pollicis longus, an issue with this muscle would impact thumb movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interossei and lumbricals are the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

  • The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. They act to flex the MCP joints and extend both the proximal and distal IP joints.
  • The interossei (both dorsal and palmar) act to abduct (DAB - Dorsal Abduct) and adduct (PAD - Palmar Adduct) the fingers at the MCP joints and assist the lumbricals in flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints.
  • If these muscles are affected, as indicated in the clinical picture, there would be an extension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints (due to unopposed action of extrinsic flexors and extensors).
